p: The vaccine based on the S2 protein subunit of the spike glycoprotein (S) that helps in receptor binding and entry can have broad-spectrum antiviral effects as it is conserved in SARS-CoV-2 [ 72, 81, 201]. Targeting S1 protein of SARS-CoV-2 can prevent virus entry and hence a strategy for controlling viral infection [ 201]. Targeting S protein can both develop both cellular and humoral immunity by inducing neutralizing antibodies and by developing protective cellular immunity [ 201]. Full-length S protein [ 220], receptor-binding domain (RBD) [ 221] of SARS-CoV have shown vaccine potential and can be explored in SARS-CoV-2 [ 201]. Similarly, the S1 subunit of spike protein in SARS-CoV-2 can be studied for antibody production hence prophylactic and therapeutic target [ 72]. Both aerosol or oral routes need to be explored as possible modes of administration [ 201].
